Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation2: A few machines are running hotter than normal after missing their last service window.
Story:
I stared at my phone, my brother’s message lighting up the screen: “Hey, we’re all heading to the lake this afternoon. You coming?” I could almost hear his hopeful tone, the unspoken wish that I’d finally say yes and join the group. We’d talked about spending more time together, about not letting work get in the way. I knew how much it meant to him, to both of us, to build that kind of respect and closeness.

But as I glanced over at the machines humming in the workshop, my stomach tightened. The last service window had slipped by during last week’s rush, and now a few of the units were running hotter than they should. If I didn’t get to them soon, I risked a breakdown—maybe even a shutdown that would cost the company dearly. My supervisor had made it clear: maintenance was my top priority, and any slip-ups would be on me.

I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, the pull of family and the push of responsibility. My hands hovered over the keyboard, torn between replying to my brother and logging another maintenance report, my mind wrestling with the impossible choice.
